points.digest: The incidence of hepatitis A depends on socioeconomic conditions. With increasing incomes, and with access to clean water and adequate sanitation, the incidence decreases. In endemic countries, almost everyone tolerates asymptomatic infection in childhood, which effectively prevents clinical hepatitis among adolescents and adults, WHO does not recommend universal vaccination in these countries.

points.title: Type A viral hepatitis: epidemiology, diagnosis, and prevention.
points.digest: Hepatitis A deaths of 70-80 people a year in the US, and it's almost exclusively people over the age of 50. Severe manifestations of hepatitis A are more likely in people with alcoholic liver disease or with chronic hepatitis. some vaccines started Guillain-Barre syndrome, but it is not known for sure whether this is due to vaccination.

points.title: Hospitalization and mortality due to hepatitis A in Taiwan: a 15-year nationwide cohort study.
points.digest:
In Taiwan, hepatitis A has been vaccinated by the native population since 1995. One study found that the incidence in Taiwan decreased more than 3-fold due to vaccination, despite the fact that only 2% of the population had been vaccinated, and the majority of those vaccinated lived in the mountains and isolated islands.
In another study, it was found that only 0.4% of the unvaccinated population had antibodies to hepatitis A, from which the authors conclude that hygiene is more responsible for reducing morbidity than vaccination. improved hygiene emost shifted from children at an older age.

Israel was the first country in the world to add the hepatitis A vaccine to the national vaccination calendar in 1999. For three years, the incidence of hepatitis A fell by more than 98% among vaccinated children and by 95% among the entire population Before vaccination, 47% of the Jewish population had antibodies, and after 12 years they were already at 67% .In the Arab population, 83% had antibodies before vaccination, and after 12 years they were 88%. , as well as in Taiwan, not the fact that only the vaccine was responsible for reducing the incidence of disease.
points.title: Seroprevalence of Hepatitis A Twelve Years After the Implementation of Toddlers Vaccination: A Population-Based Study in Israel.

points.digest: Only in two European countries is the hepatitis A vaccine [included==https://vaccine-schedule.ecdc.europa.eu/Scheduler/ByDisease?SelectedDiseaseId=16&SelectedCountryIdByDisease=-1] in the national calendar (Greece and Austria), and only in Greece the vaccine is funded by the state.

points.title: Is travel prophylaxis worth while? Economic appraisal of prophylactic measures against malaria, hepatitis A, and typhoid in travellers.
points.digest: Vaccination against hepatitis A and from typhus for those who travel to endemic countries economically inexpedient, and tablets from malaria are economically feasible. Only 1 out of 2000 was infected with hepatitis A on a trip, and in 90% of cases the disease passed It is estimated that in England the vaccination against hepatitis A prevented 0.29 deaths per year.

points.title: Cross sectional retrospective study of prevalence of atopy among Italian military students with antibodies against hepatitis A virus.
points.digest: Recruits in Italy, who had antibodies to hepatitis A, had asthma and allergic rhinitis 2 times less often than soldiers who did not have antibodies. Recruits who had older brothers also suffered from allergic diseases less often, which means that hepatitis A is not the only infection that reduces the risk of allergic diseases. In Italy, hepatitis A was an endemic disease in the 1970s, they were usually infected in childhood and passed asymptomatically. research also reveals in recent decades feedback antibodies to hepatitis A and allergies in different countries.In the United States in the 1970s, the eldest generation had more antibodies to hepatitis A than the younger generation, whereas the younger generation had more atopic diseases.

points.title: The prevalence of atopy in children with antibodies against hepatitis A virus and hepatitis B virus.
points.digest: Children who did not have antibodies against hepatitis A had 9 times more asthma and allergic rhinitis, those who did not have hepatitis B antibodies were 5.9 times more likely to have allergic diseases. More: [[1]==https://www.nature.com/articles/425576a].

points.title: Clearance of HCV RNA following acute hepatitis A superinfection.
points.digest:
Superinfection (an infection that develops against a background of another infection) of hepatitis A in chronic hepatitis B and C patients is believed to lead to liver failure and a high probability of death. However, it is also reported that hepatitis A infection can lead to complete or temporary recovery from chronic hepatitis.The mechanisms of this phenomenon are unknown.The case of a 24-year-old drug addict who had chronic hepatitis C was described. He ate raw fish and became ill with hepatitis A, after which he underwent chronic hepatitis C.
All in all, interferon gamma (cytokine secreted by Th1 cells) is responsible for this, the level of which has significantly increased after infection.
Hepatitis B suppression is also reported during hepatitis A: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11169072], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6491642], [[3]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/4088008].

Until 1966, all types of hepatitis were simply called "viral hepatitis."
Here are described 3 cases of viral hepatitis in patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma, two of whom also underwent lymphoma after hepatitis A, but the third died.
Inspired by this discovery, the authors infected hepatitis with 21 volunteers with Hodgkin's lymphoma.At the preliminary results at the time of writing, 13 of them became infected with hepatitis and 7 symptoms of lymphoma improved. At the time of writing, no one died.
points.title: Studies in Hodgkin's syndrome, the association of viral hepatitis and Hodgkin's disease; a preliminary report.

points.digest:
Before the licensing of the vaccine, the incidence of hepatitis A in the United States was approximately 1 per 10,000 and the death rate 1 per 3 million. In 1999, vaccination was introduced in 11 states where the incidence was higher than 1 in 5,000.
The vaccine was added to the national immunization schedule in 2006. The incidence of hepatitis A at this point [was==https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/ss5803a1.htm] 1 per 100,000, and the mortality [was====https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/appendices/e/reported-cases.pdf] 1 by ten million, and almost all of the deceased were over 50, with concomitant diseases.

points.title: Autoimmunity and hepatitis A vaccine in children.
points.digest:
There are no accepted criteria for diagnosing autoimmune diseases due to vaccination, autoimmune diseases start long after vaccination and it is difficult to conclude a causal relationship. Vaccines contain adjuvants, preservatives, antigens and other ingredients, each of which can cause or exacerbate autoimmune reactions.
The authors injected 40 children from hepatitis A, and 25% of them formed autoantibodies (antibodies to their own antigens), one developed temporary leukopenia (with izhenie white blood cell count). One year after vaccination in two children still identified autoantibodies.

In clinical trials of Vaqta as a placebo [used==https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/ApprovedProducts/UCM110049.pdf] aluminum.
1-10% of vaccinated children Conjunctivitis, otitis media, anorexia, insomnia and other diseases were observed within 14 days after vaccination, and menstrual irregularities and back pain were also observed in adults. 0.7% of those vaccinated had serious adverse events, and 0.1% had, according to researchers, are associated with the vaccine.
In clinical trials of Havrix as a placebo [used==https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/Approvedproducts/UCM224555.pdf] vaccine against hepatitis B.
0.9% of vaccinated experienced serious adverse events.

points.title: Hepatitis A virus infections and outbreaks in asylum seekers arriving to Germany, September 2015 to March 2016.
points.digest: In 2015-16, the number of hepatitis A cases in Germany, which was constantly decreasing, increased by 45%, and the average age of the patients decreased significantly, it turned out that this is due to the million refugees that Germany accepted.

points.title: Hepatitis A outbreak in the USA.
points.digest:
In 2001, the advisory committee of San Diego (California) stressed the need to increase the number of public toilets in the city center.
In 2010, he developed a plan for financing these toilets.
Two toilets were installed in 2016. One of them were subsequently closed due to operational costs and fear of crime, and only one toilet remained working in 2017. In total, San Diego had 8 public toilets, but only three were available 24 hours a day.
In San Francisco, where the number of homeless people compared Imo with San Diego, there are 25 public toilets and everyone is open 24 hours a day.
In 2017, a hepatitis A outbreak in the United States began, affecting mostly the homeless in San Diego, where more than 500 were sick and 20 died. 16 portable toilets are installed.
Because of fear of hepatitis A, authorities [are arrested==http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-homeless-feeding-arrests-20180115-story.html] those who distribute food to the homeless in the suburbs of San Diego.

points.title: Outbreak of hepatitis A associated with men who have sex with men (MSM), England, July 2016 to January 2017.
points.digest:
In 2016-17 large cities in Europe swept the wave of outbreaks of hepatitis A. The vast majority of cases were homosexuals.
In England, there were 37 cases.

points.title: Hepatitis A outbreak in Barcelona among men who have sex with men (MSM), January-June 2017: A hospital perspective.
points.digest: 46 cases were registered in the Barcelona hospital, 96% of them men, and 67% identified themselves as homosexuals. The authors write that the main risk factor is oral-anal contact during sex that the last outbreaks in Europe were between 2008 and 2011, and that because of these outbreaks, hepatitis A has been classified as an STD.

points.title: Ongoing outbreaks of hepatitis A among men who have sex with men (MSM), Berlin, November 2016 to January 2017 - linked to other German cities and European countries.
points.digest:
Outbreak in Berlin: 38 cases, 37 men, 30 reported homosexual relationships. The woman also reported same-sex relationships.
One of the patients was vaccinated 11 months before the onset of the illness.
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5695276/] outbreaks are reported in Rome and its environs, 513 cases, of which 87.5% are men. [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29380498]
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5695276/] reported an outbreak in Tel Aviv, 19 cases, from there are 17 homosexuals. [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29380498]
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5695276/] reported that only 16 European there were 1500 cases of hepatitis A, and 2,660 unacknowledged cases, mostly among homosexuals. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5695276/] it is reported that from January to August 2017, 11,212 cases were registered in Europe, mainly among homosexuals.
WHO [reports==http://www.who.int/csr/don/07-june-2017-hepatitis -a/ en/] also about the outbreak among homosexuals in Chile.

points.title: Hepatitis A outbreak among men who have sex with men (MSM), predominantly linked with the EuroPride, the Netherlands, July 2016 to February 2017.
points.digest: It all started with a gay parade in Amsterdam in 2016, which attracted half a million visitors.In total, the Netherlands recorded 48 cases among men.

points.title: Hepatitis A outbreak in HIV-infected MSM and in PrEP-using MSM despite the high level of immunity, Lyon, France, January to June 2017.
points.digest:
The outbreak of hepatitis A in Lyon in the first half of 2017. 46 cases, 38 of them men, 33 homosexuals, and 15 infected with HIV Most were vaccinated or had antibodies. According to the available model, 70% who have immunity to prevent hepatitis A infection among homosexuals.The authors conclude that 70% is not enough.
It is also reported that since it is possible to get hepatitis A from the reuse of needles, [slamming==http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/experts-warn-of-rise-in-gay-slamming-9069571.html] (intravenous drug use during anal sex contact) - a practice that is gaining popularity among some groups of homosexuals may also increase the risk of the disease. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28534888], [[2 ]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28510643].

points.title: Hepatitis A Outbreak Among Men Who Have Sex With Men in a Country of Low Endemicity of Hepatitis A Infection.
points.digest: Hepatitis A outbreak in Taiwan: More than 1,000 cases, 70% of them homosexuals, 60% infected with HIV, and more than 60% were infected with syphilis, gonorrhea or shigellosis. It is not mentioned anywhere that in all of these outbreaks someone died of hepatitis A.

In VAERS [registered==http://www.medalerts.org/vaersdb/findfield.php?TABLE=ON&GROUP1=CAT&VAX[]=HEPA&VAX[]=HEPAB&VAX[]=HEPATYP] 131 deaths after vaccination against hepatitis A, 773 disability cases, and 3888 [serious==http://www.medalerts.org/vaersdb/findfield.php?TABLE=ON&GROUP1=AGE&GROUP2=VCT&GRAPH=ON&GROUP6=AGE&EVENTS=ON&VAX[]=HEPA&VAX[]=HEPAB&VAX[]=HEPATYP&SERIOUS=ON] Negative cases: Before the vaccination, there were almost no deaths of children from hepatitis A.

epigraph.text: Vaccination is a barbarous practice, and it is one of the most fatal of all the delusions of the world. Conscientious objectors to vaccination should stand alone, if need be, against the whole world, in defense of their conviction.

points.digest: Before the advent of the vaccine, few people heard of rotavirus infection, despite the fact that almost all children were ill.

Rotavirus was discovered in 1973, and it was named because it looks like a wheel. The virus is the most common causative agent of gastroenteritis in infants and children.It is transmitted by fecal-oral route.
First infection after 3 of the month of age usually passes the hardest, it can be asymptomatic, can cause mild diarrhea, and can have severe diarrhea with fever and vomiting.The symptoms usually last for 3-7 days.Such symptoms can cause not only rotavirus, but other pathogens, so for confirmation you need a lab In the temperate climate, the disease is more common in autumn and winter.
There are currently two oral rotavirus vaccines: Rotatec and Rotarix.Rotatec is given 3 doses (at 2, 4 and 6 months), and Rotarix has two dose (at 2 and 4 months.) The first dose can not be given after 14 weeks, and the last dose can not be given after 8 months.
Vaccines are effective from the serotypes contained in them by 74-98%.How long does immunity last?
Since the efficacy and safety of more than one dose is not investigated, it is not recommended to give the infant another dose of vaccine if it spits out or spits up.
In clinical trials in Rotatec vaccines, diarrhea and vomiting were more frequent in the first week after vaccination than in the placebo group. Within 42 days after vaccination, vaccinians were more likely to have diarrhea, vomiting, otitis media, nasopharyngitis and bronchospasm.
The vaccinated Rotarix had more frequent cough and runny nose for 7 days, and irritability and flatulence more often appeared within a month after vaccination, compared with a "placebo"-group.
points.title: CDC Pinkbook Rotavirus
Rotavirus infection in infants as protection against subsequent infections.
points.digest:
The probability of diarrhea in primary rotavirus infection is 47%. In subsequent infections, the likelihood of diarrhea decreases.
Diarrhea caused by rotavirus reduces the risk of diarrhea from subsequent infections by 77% and the risk of severe diarrhea by 87%. diarrhea from rotavirus reduces the risk of subsequent infections by 83%/92%.
The transferred asymptomatic infection reduces the risk of subsequent infections by 38%.
Two transmitted infections (unimportant, symptomatic or asymptomatic) give 100% protection from severe diarrhea The short period of breastfeeding hides the risk of rotavirus infection.

points.title: Human immunity to rotavirus.
points.digest:
Repeated infection with rotavirus is possible, but it passes with mild symptoms or is asymptomatic. In total there are 7 serotype groups of the virus (A-G).Group A is divided into serotypes G1-G14, P1-P11 and others. mainly serotypes G1-G4 of group A, and less often in groups B and C. Infants usually get asymptomatic in newborns and subsequently become less likely to get sick with rotavirus than those who have not been infected after birth.Infection in infancy, symptomatic or asymptomatic, gives protection for 2 years. After a period of early childhood and symptomatic infection occurs rarely.
Exclusive breastfeeding for the first year of life reduces the risk of infection.

points.title: Diarrheal deaths in American children. Are they preventable?
points.digest:
In the 1990s, vaccines for rotavirus were being developed, so the CDC wondered how many children die from it, for this they conducted the following studies.

Deaths from diarrhea (from all causes) account for 2% of all post-neonatal deaths.In 1983, 500 children died of diarrhea in the United States, 50% of whom died in the hospital.The mortality from diarrhea falls sharply with age, it is twice as high among infants at the age of 1-3 months compared to with 4-6 months, and 10 times higher compared with 12-month.
The risk of death from diarrhea is 4 times higher among non-diarrhea. (and in some states 10 times higher) than among whites, 5 times higher among infants whose mothers are under the age of 17, 2 times higher among those whose parents are unmarried, 3 times higher among those whose parents do not The mortality from diarrhea is higher in winter than in summer, and it is believed that rotavirus is responsible for it.It is estimated that 70-80 children a year die from rotavirus.

points.title: Trends of diarrheal disease - associated mortality in US children, 1968 through 1991.
points.digest:
Between 1968 and 1985, deaths from diarrhea in the United States declined by 75% (among infants - 79%), and then stabilized, between 1985 and 1991, 300 people died a year from diarrhea, among them 240 children, the lethality of diarrhea among children was 1: 17,000 Since 1985, half of them died before reaching 1.5 months of age (that is, up to the vaccination age).
Here is the graph of mortality from diarrhea from 1968 to 1991.
Every winter it is possible to observe death peaks that disappear in the mid-1980s, and only small peaks remain in the group of 4-23 month old children.As rotavirus is affected almost and exclusively in the winter, the authors believe that this is the death from rotavirus.
The authors conclude that a vaccine against rotavirus will have a measurable but small impact on mortality from diarrhea.

points.title: The epidemiology of rotavirus diarrhea in the United States: surveillance and estimates of disease burden.
points.digest:
It is estimated that 873 thousand people die annually from rotavirus, but there was no information on the lethality of rotavirus in developed countries, and therefore in 1985 IOM concluded that this vaccine was not a priority for the US But they were based in one prospective study, although other studies have found that a third of children hospitalized with diarrhea have a rotavirus infection. Since no child in the US died with a diagnosis of rotavirus diarrhea, many pediatricians believed that rotavirus never occurs heavy or lethal, but analysis of mortality data (in previous studies) provided convincing, albeit indirect, evidence that rotavirus is still dying. Based on two previous studies, the authors calculate that 55,000 children are hospitalized per rotavirus per year, and 20 children die, ie 1 in 200 000. They believe that these children have some other disease, or they are premature, for example. The authors conclude that less than 40 children die annually from rotavirus, although they nowhere explain where they got 40, if in the text of art. Atiyah, they counted only 20.
CDC [write==https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/rota.html] that 20-60 children die per rotavirus per year, but do not explain, from where they took 60 children, if their studies counted only 20.

points.title: Rotavirus vaccines: viral shedding and risk of transmission.
points.digest:
The first rotavirus vaccine was licensed in 1998 and contained 4 strains, which was withdrawn in 1999 because it was associated with https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11207352] with intussusception [Intussusception==https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intussusception] is when a part of the intestine develops itself as a telescope.
- The public does not wants to tolerate even a small risk of serious side effects, even as low as 1 per 10,000.
Rotarix (GSK) vaccine was licensed in 1998. Contains one strain. The infected child was [weakened==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9607059] through 33 serial transitions through the kidney cells of African green monkeys.The vaccine strain multiplies well in the human intestine. The Rotateq (Merck) vaccine was licensed in 1996. It contains 5 strains. (Our friend Paul Offit [has==https://patents.justia.com/inventor/paul-offit] 4 patents for this vaccine.)
difference from other live vaccines, Rotatec is not a weakened vaccine, but reassortant.
The genome of rotavirus consists of 11 segments of RNA. In vaccine strains of Rotatek, part of the segments was replaced with human rotavirus by bovine rotavirus. Such vaccines, where some segments of the virus RNA are replaced by segments of animal strains of the virus, are called reassortant vaccines. Rotatec is a pentavalent vaccine. The four most common serotypes (G1-G4) are combined with bovine serotype P. The fifth strain consists of a bovine serotype G combined with human serotype P. Three vaccine strains [reassortant==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23249230/] from one human and ten bull segments. The remaining two are reassortant from two human and nine bull segments. This virus reproduces badly in the intestine, so Rotatec contains 100 times more viral particles than Rotarix.
The first vaccine (Rotashield) was also reassortant, but it used segments of the monkey virus.
The vaccine contains polysorbate 80 and embryonic bovine serum.
In clinical trials of both vaccines, the same vaccine was used as a placebo, but without the virus [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16621194/], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16394298].

(Shedding)
- During the clinical trials of Rotashield, vaccine strains began found out in the stool those who received a placebo a year after the start of the test, and stopped detecting 100 days after their end, which indicates the establishment of a "public reservoir."
In clinical trials, Rotarix found that approximately 50-80 % of babies secrete the virus after the first dose. A study in Singapore found that 80% of infants isolated the virus on day 7 after vaccination, and 20% continued to secrete it one month after vaccination. In a study in the Dominican Republic, [found==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22008819/] that 19% of unvaccinated twins contracted a vaccine strain from their vaccinated brothers.
- After the first dose of Rotatec, 13% of infants isolate the virus. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21477676/] it is reported that 21% of infants isolate the virus after Rotatec, and [here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29149283], which is 87%.
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21856359/] it is reported that among preterm infants, 53% isolated the virus after Rotatec.
- It is believed that the isolation of the vaccine virus and its spread is nezel a significant side effect. However this one also has potential benefit. Infection of the unvaccinated will develop their immunity, as well as it does with the vaccine against poliomyelitis. Particularly significant benefits will be achieved by this effect in poor countries, where vaccination coverage is low, mortality is high, and immunodeficient people are few. Of course, in developed countries, where mortality is low, and there are many immunodeficiency people, and most people prefer to avoid risk, the isolation of vaccine strains can be considered as a hindrance.
In 1 gram of feces of an infected child, 100 billion virus particles are contained. Only 10 particles are sufficient for infection. Therefore, adults who change diapers to babies risk themselves. Immunodeficient people should not change diapers to a vaccinated infant, especially within 2 weeks after Rotatec, and 4 weeks after Rotarix.

Exclusive breastfeeding reduces the risk of rotavirus infection by 38%. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23713234], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26828823], [[3]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28735327], [[4]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28592985], [[5]==https://academic.oup.com/tropej/article-abstract/30/3/131/1688093], [[6]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20617343], [[7]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12394379], [[8]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11825046].
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25355609] is reported , that in breast milk in mothers in Sweden there were much more antibodies from rotavirus in spring than in autumn. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27217217] it is reported that the level of zinc at blood is correlated with protection against rotavirus. Late vaccination (at 17 weeks) is more effective than vaccination at 10 weeks.
points.title: Effect of exclusive breastfeeding on rotavirus infection among children.
Inhibitory effect of breast milk on infectivity of live oral rotavirus vaccines.
points.digest:
In poor countries, rotavirus vaccines are less immunogenic and less effective than in developed countries.If Rotarix induces an immune response in more than 90% of infants in Finland, in South America only 70%, and in South Africa, Malawi, Bangladesh, and India - 40-60%. Other oral vaccines (against poliomyelitis and cholera) are also less effective in poor countries.
Why this is still unknown, but one possible explanation is that mothers in these countries are more likely to feed breastfeeding during vaccination, and mothers in poor countries often have natures immunity to rotavirus, which is expressed in more antibodies in breast milk and IgG antibodies transmitted through the placenta. The authors took samples of mother's milk from India, Vietnam, South Korea and the United States and checked whether it has an inhibitory effect on It turned out that in the samples of mother's milk from India there were the most antibodies to rotavirus, in milk from Vietnam and South Korea they were less, and in milk from the US they were the least. The authors recommend developing parenteral vaccines from rotavirus, and to investigate, by whether the restriction of GV during vaccination affects its immunogenicity. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21147127]. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3967577/] reported that abstinence from HB one hour before and one hour after vaccination does not affect the immunogenicity of the vaccine. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25091668], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26035743].

points.title: Vaccines for preventing rotavirus diarrhoea: vaccines in use.
points.digest:
Systematic review of Cochrane.In developed countries, vaccination reduces the risk of diarrhea by about 40%, and the risk of severe rotavirus diarrhea by 86%.

Vaccination has not been found to reduce mortality.
Severe Adverse Events (SAE) were registered with 4.6% of the grafted Rotarix and 2.4% of the vaccinated Rotatec.In the "placebo" groups, a similar amount of SAE was recorded.

points.title: Cost-effectiveness and potential impact of rotavirus vaccination in the United States.
points.digest: Rotavirus vaccination in the United States will prevent 63% of all rotavirus cases and 79% of all serious cases, leading to the prevention of 13 deaths and 44,000 hospitalizations per year. At a vaccine dose price of more than $ 12, vaccination will not be economical justified from the point of view of health care, and at a dose rate of more than $ 42 it will not be justified from the perspective of society. Today Rotatec [costs==https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/vfc/awardees/vaccine-management/price- list/index.html] $69- $83 per dose, and Rotarix $91- $110. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18301365].

points.title: Effectiveness of monovalent rotavirus vaccine (Rotarix) against severe diarrhea caused by serotypically unrelated G2P [4] strains in Brazil.
points.digest: In Brazil, the strain of rotavirus G2P(4), which occurred in 19%-30% of cases before vaccination, changed all other strains 15 months after vaccination began. The vaccine (Rotarix) efficacy against this strain was 77% among children 6-11 months, and -24% (negative) among children over 12 months. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22795600], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26422154]. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26748357] reported that after the initiation of vaccination in Brazil, the common strains of rotavirus were replaced by a new strain of G12P(8) The replacement of the strains also occurred in Paraguay https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20213281] and in [Argentina==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24875137].

points.title: Effectiveness of the monovalent rotavirus vaccine in Colombia: a case-control study.
points.digest:
The effectiveness of the vaccine (Rotarix) in Colombia among children 6-11 months was 79%, from severe cases of diarrhea 63%, and from very severe cases 67%. Effectiveness among children over 12 months was -40% from severe cases -6%, and from very severe cases -156% (negative effectiveness). The overall effectiveness of the vaccine for all ages was -2%, from severe cases -54%, and from very severe cases -114% (negative efficiency). [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21288843] it is reported that in central Australia the effectiveness of two doses of Rotarix sost Vila 19%, and the effectiveness of one dose was zero.
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21288843] it is reported that there is no correlation between the amount of antibodies produced and the clinical effectiveness of the vaccine.

points.title: Differentiation of RotaTeq® vaccine strains from wild-type strains using NSP3 gene in reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction assay.
points.digest: The authors analyzed the stool of 1106 infants with gastroenteritis and found group A rotavirus in a quarter of them, 13.6% of the strains detected were vaccine.

points.title: Detection of rotateq vaccine-derived, double-reassortant rotavirus in a 7-year-old child with gastroenteritis.
points.digest:
Since the rotavirus genome consists of separate segments, when two different strains of the virus infect one cell, they can exchange segments and create a new strain. This is the same reassortment that takes place uncontrollably.
Here is reported the case of gastroenteritis in a seven-year-old girl, a rotavirus strain was isolated from her stool, which was a reassortment of two other human-bovine strains from the Rotakek vaccine, but the girl was not vaccinated against rotavirus, and she had no contact with anyone who was Her two brothers also had similar symptoms of gastroenteritis, they also were not vaccinated, and did not come into contact with vaccinated.
The isolated reassortant strain of the virus proved to be stable and very contagious.The authors believe that this new virus is likely to circulate among the population. Previously, reassortant strains have already been isolated, but only in newly vaccinated Rotatec: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22581224], [[2]==https://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22872730], [[3]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24817171]. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24188273] the discovery of new strains against the reassortment of dick virus with the Rotarix vaccine strain. [Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25260041] it is reported that 17% of children isolated the virus after vaccination, and 37% of them were isolated twice reassortant virus. Some children isolated the virus a long time after vaccination, 9 to 84 days after the last dose.

points.title: Vaccine-derived NSP2-segment in rotaviruses from vaccinated children with gastroenteritis in Nicaragua.
points.digest: The authors analyzed the rotavirus genome in vaccinated children with gastroenteritis in Nicaragua, and discovered new strains of the virus that formed due to reassortment between the wild strain and the vaccine strains from Rotatec.

points.title: Identification of strains of RotaTeq rotavirus vaccine in infants with gastroenteritis following routine vaccination.
points.digest: Among children who had diarrhea within two weeks after vaccination, 21% were sick from the vaccine strain. Of the isolated vaccine strains, 37% were strains that were reassortant from the two vaccine strains of Rotatec.

points.title: Rotavirus infection frequency and risk of celiac disease autoimmunity in early childhood: a longitudinal study.
points.digest: Frequent rotavirus infections are associated with an increased risk of celiac disease. HLA-DQ2 (a gene whose expression is associated with celiac disease) is found in 20-30% of healthy white people, but less than 1% of the population has celiac disease More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16984219/].

points.title: Rotavirus immunization and type 1 diabetes mellitus: A nested case-control study.
points.digest: The incidence of type 1 diabetes among children under the age of 18 in Israel increased by 6% per year between 2000 and 2008. And among children under 5 years of age, it [increased==https://www.ncbi. nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21166845] by 104% in 6 years, the authors suggested that one of the factors of the disease are viral infections, which means that vaccination against rotavirus may reduce the risk of diabetes. However, it turned out that vaccinated people developed diabetes the first type is 7.4 times more unvaccinated.

After the start of rotavirus vaccination in France, 508 side effects (of which 201 serious) and 47 intussusception were recorded, 2 infants died from intussusception, and one died from necrotizing enterocolitis. there was only one case of death from intussusception in France in vaccination.
Therefore, the rotavirus vaccine was not included in the national vaccination schedule and is not funded by the state.
In clinical studies, vaccines have not been established that about vaccination reduces overall mortality, neither in developed nor in developing countries.
points.title: Rotavirus vaccines in France: because of the three infant deaths and too many serious side effects vaccines are no longer recommended for routine children immunization.

points.digest: Merck [reports==https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/ApprovedProducts/UCM142288.pdf], that in the clinical trials of Rotatec, the risk of epileptic seizure in vaccinated patients was increased 2-fold with the placebo group Kawasaki syndrome was registered in 5 vaccinated Rotatec and one in the placebo group.In premature infants, serious adverse events were reported in 5.5% of the vaccinated and 5.8% of those receiving the placebo. GSK [reports==https://www.fda.gov/downloads/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/ApprovedProducts/UCM142288.pdf] that in the Rotarix clinical trials mortality was 0.19% in the pr. and 0.15% in the placebo group.The risk of Kawasaki syndrome in vaccinees was increased by 71%. [Here==https://www.reuters.com/article/us-glaxo-rotavirus/pneumonia-deaths-seen -with-glaxo-vaccine-fda-idUSN1556886020080215] reported that, in the largest clinical trial of Rotarix (63,000 children), there were 2.7 times more deaths from pneumonia in the vaccinated group than in the placebo group. The FDA [considers==https://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/08/transcripts/2008-4348T1.DOC] that this is most likely an accident. It is possible that the vaccine increases the risk of Kawasaki syndrome. More [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18301365], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26158590/].

In 2010, a group of independent researchers accidentally [discovered==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2876658] in the Rotarix vaccine of porcine circovirus PCV1, and the FDA decided to suspend the vaccination. The FDA [stated==http://wayback.archive-it.org/7993/20170113185832/http://www.fda.gov/BiologicsBloodVaccines/Vaccines/ApprovedProducts/ucm207886.htm] that Rotatec does not contain a pork virus, but through two months later it was discovered that Rotatec contains two pig viruses PCV1 and PCV2 The FDA assembled a committee that concluded that these viruses are likely harmless to humans and that the benefits of vaccination outweighed hypothetical harm. Also recommended manufacturers to develop vaccines without pig viruses. A week after the detection of viruses in Rotatec, the FDA recommended that pediatricians continue vaccination with both vaccines, since 8 years have passed, but manufacturers are slow to develop vaccines without swine viruses.
In this study, the authors wanted to determine , whether pork viruses multiply in the human intestine. They did not find pork viruses, but found the endogenous M7 baboon virus in the Rotatec vaccine, which probably got there from the kidney cells of the green African monkeys on which the virus for the vaccine is grown.
In the Chinese vaccine [use==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29165219] a sheep strain of rotavirus that is grown on the kidney cells of cows, and the swine virus in the vaccines has not been found. [Here==http://www.nationalhogfarmer.com/health-diseases/0301-porcine-circovirus-more-deadly] reported that the PCV2 swine virus, which is known for 40 years, and was harmless, suddenly mutated, spread camping all over the world, they began to get sick pigs, and it became fatal for pigs. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22192532]

[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22695189] it is reported that in Mexico Rotarix increased the risk of intussusception of the intestine 6.5 times.

Meta-analysis of 11 studies. The first dose of rotavirus vaccine increases the risk of intussusception 3.5-8.5 times.
Another study confirming the increased risk of intussusception after vaccination: [[1]==https://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23669521], [[2]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21675888], [[3]==https://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28468712], [[4]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26069948], [[5]==https://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3560585/]. points.title: Risk of intussusception following rotavirus vaccination: An evidence-based meta-analysis of cohort and case-control studies.
Rotavirus vaccine and intussusception: how much risk will parents in the United States take to obtain vaccine benefits?
points.digest:
Despite the obvious benefits of vaccination, no vaccine is completely safe. Post-clinical studies have shown that a newly licensed rotavirus vaccine increases the risk of intussusception, but it is not known what risk will be tolerable for parents and how much they will agree to pay For reaching 50% coverage, parents are ready to tolerate 2,897 cases of intussusception per year, which will result in 579 surgeries and 17 additional deaths. And to achieve 90% coverage, ro There are no more than 1,794 cases of intussusception, including 359 surgeries and 11 deaths from vaccines.
Without vaccination against rotavirus, 20 children die.
The lower the income of parents, the more risk they agree.
Parents agree to pay $110 for three doses of a risk-free vaccine, but only $36 for three doses of a risky vaccine.
In other studies, it has already been determined that parents prefer death from disease rather than from vaccines, and this study confirms this fact.

Two twins were vaccinated with Rotarix, a week later, one of them developed symptoms of intussusception of the intestines, and he was promptly operated on. A few hours after the operation, another twin began to have similar symptoms, and he also underwent surgery. urgently.
points.title: Post-rotavirus vaccine intussusception in the identical twins: A case report.
An infant with a gastroenteritis caused by a secondary infection with a Rotarix-derived strain.
points.digest:
A two-month-old girl in Japan was vaccinated by Rotarix, and 10 days later her two-year-old sister was hospitalized with severe gastroenteritis. It turned out that she contracted from her sister the vaccine strain of the virus that mutated.
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20100758] reported exactly the same case in the US with Rotatec vaccine.The vaccinated infant infected his brother with a rotavirus strain, reassortant from two vaccine strains 10 days later.

points.title: Persistent rotavirus vaccine shedding in a new case of severe combined immunodeficiency: A reason to screen.
points.digest: Immunodeficient infants after vaccination may be ill with severe gastroenteritis for a long time, but at the age of two months, when vaccination is carried out, it is still unknown whether the infant is immunodeficient or not. The authors suggest that children be tested for congenital genetic defects before vaccination. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103739/].

For the 10 years between 2007 and 2016 in VAERS was [registered==http://www.medalerts.org/vaersdb/findfield.php?TABLE=ON&GROUP1=CAT&VAX[]=RV&VAX[]=RV1&VAX[]=RV5&VAX[]=RVX&VAXTYPES[]=Rotavirus&VAX_YEAR_LOW=2007&VAX_YEAR_HIGH=2016] 514 deaths and 230 disabilities after the rotavirus vaccine Before the start of the vaccination, 20 deaths were recorded in the year, i.e. 1:200,000 (and even they, not the fact that it is from rotavirus).
Given that in VAERS 1%-10% of all cases are registered, the probability of dying after vaccination is 25-250 times higher, than the probability of dying from rotavirus.

points.digest: Scientists usually allocate very few grants for research on the safety of vaccinations, adjuvants and other vaccine components. However, there is more than enough money to research why people are not vaccinated, and how to make them vaccinate their children. Therefore, there are many studies characterizing anti-invasive parents.

It is believed that anti-vaccination is usually uneducated, religious and anti-scientific people. However, scientific evidence suggests otherwise. Most anti-vaccines are well-educated and wealthy.
In some private schools in Los Angeles, less than 20% of children are [vaccinated==http://www.latimes.com/opinion/opinion-la/la-oe-shapiro-schools-and-vaccination-rates-20130811-story.html]. How can it be that these rich and educated people do not vaccinate their children? Do they not know that vaccinations are completely safe, and that they protect against terrible diseases? Or maybe they know something about vaccinations that others do not?

Here are a few studies:
Unvaccinated children are mostly white. Their mothers are over 30, married, have an academic degree, and their families earn more than $ 75,000 a year. (USA)

points.digest:
If the doctor says "we will do the flu vaccine today," 72% of parents agree. And if the doctor asks, “are we going to be vaccinated for flu today?”, Only 17% agree.
If a doctor recommends a flu shot along with any other vaccine, then 83% of parents agree. And if the doctor offers a separate flu vaccine, then only 33% agree to do it. Doctors should note.

points.title: Greater freedom of speech on Web 2.0 correlates with dominance of views linking vaccines to autism.
points.digest:
The authors of this study analyzed YouTube, Google, Wikipedia and Pubmed, and came to the conclusion that the more freedom of speech on a resource, the more it associates vaccines with autism. Freedom of speech on YouTube is highest, in Google it is less, and in Wikipedia and Pubmed it is very low. This leads to the fact that on YouTube 75% of the videos link vaccinations with autism, in Google 41% of the links, in Wikipedia 14% of the articles, and in Pubmed 17% of the articles link the vaccines with autism (more than in Wikipedia!).
But the worst thing is, the authors note that anti-vaccine activists use scientific arguments (!), Doctors (!), Famous people and personal stories to inspire confidence! The problem is, they write, that YouTube, unlike Google, does not give priority to scientific authorities in search ads.
Doctors participated in 36% of the anti-vaccine ads, and only 28% of the pro-vaccination ads.
The authors of the study propose to moderate the Internet, and also urge medical institutions to be more active there.

[Here==www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/1369118X.2017.1418406] the authors analyzed the anti-vaccination movement on Facebook, and concluded that the majority of participants in anti-vaccination groups are women.
In this study, the authors analyzed 22 anti-invasive sites, and concluded that anti-vaccination sites are against vaccinations.

points.digest: More recently, chickenpox has been an innocuous childhood disease, but year after year it becomes more dangerous, and the hour is near when it becomes more dangerous than measles, which is more dangerous than Ebola.

Chickenpox (chicken pox) is caused by the virus Varicella-zoster. The same virus causes and shingles.
Adults suffer from chickenpox more heavily and the risk of complications is higher. The risk of complications is higher also in children with lymphoma, leukemia and HIV.
Before the vaccination, the chickenpox mortality rate among children 1-14 years old was 1 per 100,000, and among the 15-19 year olds 2.7 per 100,000.The chickenpox mortality rate among adults was 25.2 per 100,000, and adults accounted for 5% of cases chickenpox, but 35% of deaths.
Chickenpox is very contagious. Less than measles, but more than mumps and reds ear.
Chickenpox during pregnancy can lead to congenital defects. The risk of congenital chickenpox syndrome due to maternal illness is less than 2%. [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23442479]
The chickenpox during labor is very dangerous for the baby and its lethality is 30%.
The chickenpox vaccine was developed in the 70's and licensed in the US in 1995. The vaccine virus is weakened by serial transitions through fetal lung cells, embryonic fibroblasts of guinea pigs and diploid human cells (WI-38). The virus in the Merck vaccine was serially conducted 31 more times through diploid cells of MRC-5. The vaccine also contains embryonic bovine serum. The vaccination produces fewer antibodies than a natural disease. In the early 2000s, there were outbreaks of chickenpox in schools where almost everyone was vaccinated. Therefore, another dose of vaccine was added in 2006.
The combined measles-mumps-rubella-chickenpox vaccine (MMRV) was licensed based on immunogenicity (antibody level), and not on the basis of clinical efficacy. was vaccinated against chickenpox within 30 days after MMR, the vaccine was 2.5 times less effective.
[Reye's syndrome==https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reye_syndrome] is a rare but very dangerous disease resulting from the treatment of chickenpox (and other viral diseases) with aspirin. Therefore, it is not recommended to take aspirin within 6 weeks after vaccination.
points.title: CDC Pinkbook

points.digest:
For many years medicine has not paid much attention to chickenpox, which was only perceived as a child's rite, but we can not continue to treat it lightly. The chickenpox can be a serious and even fatal disease. Fortunately, we have a vaccine and antiviral drugs.
A chickenpox is similar to polio, in the sense that a serious illness is partly a consequence of progress in developed countries. The nature of the disease radically changed after Sidney Farber came up with chemotherapy. but overshadowed when a boy surviving chemotherapy was killed by chickenpox, which can be fatal in immunodeficient conditions. When the medicines that weakened immunity became widespread, chicken pox could no longer be considered an innocuous child ritual.It became a disease that was feared and avoided.The first steps in solving this iatrogenic problem were undertaken by Thomas Weller, who isolated the virus. This feat was a prerequisite for the development of the vaccine.
The spread of chemotherapy, steroids and antimetab olits that are used to treat autoimmune diseases or to suppress immunity for organ transplants, and increased life expectancy, have led to not only chickenpox, but shingles, which have become a serious clinical problem. Thus, it became necessary to control the chickenpox virus, which became increasingly dangerous.
points.title: Pathogenesis and current approaches to control of varicella-zoster virus infections.

points.digest:
The vaccine strain of the virus is produced through serial transitions through the cellular culture of animals, resulting in the virus weakening, but how can you be sure that this procedure really weakens the virus? The hypothesis that chicken pox and shingles are caused by one and the same the same virus, was proposed in 1909. To test it, in 1925 and in 1932, researchers extracted fluid from the vesicles in patients with shingles, and injected it to children who had not yet had chickenpox. 50% of these children developed chickenpox, but they had a rash not so strong as usual, that is, if the virus transmitted by airborne droplets is injected, it causes an atypical disease, which means that it can not be concluded that the vaccine strain of the virus is weakened only on the basis that it causes lungs Symptoms: It is also possible that the administered dose of the virus is not sufficient to induce normal symptoms.
In this study, the authors inoculated children with leukemia, and checked how often they infect their healthy brethren. It turned out that only 17% of brothers and sisters became infected. Since the wild strain of the virus infects 80%-90%, the authors concluded that the vaccine strain of the virus is indeed weakened.
points.title: Live attenuated varicella vaccine: evidence that the virus is attenuated and the importance of skin lesions in transmission of varicella-zoster virus. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases Varicella Vaccine Collaborative Study Group.

points.digest: In the first year after vaccination, the effectiveness of the vaccination is 97%, and then decreases to 84%. Vaccination before the 15-month age is less effective. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm. nih.gov/pubmed/12897314].

A chickenpox outbreak in a kindergarten where 66% were vaccinated, the effectiveness of the vaccine was 44%. After 3 years, the effectiveness of the vaccine decreased 2.6 times. The vaccine had less rash than the unvaccinated. He started a vaccinated boy who infected half his class who had not had it yet, he himself contracted an 11-year-old sister who was ill with shingles.
The effectiveness of the vaccine was much lower than that established in clinical trials, most probably because in clinical trials, children who have not developed an The cells were inoculated again, or excluded from the efficacy analysis, or were analyzed separately, which led to overestimated efficacy.
[Here==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17706845] meta-analysis 14 studies of outbreaks of chickenpox The effectiveness of a single dose of vaccine was 72.5%.

points.digest:
A chickenpox outbreak in a school where 98.6% were vaccinated, 63.2% of them were given in two doses. Among the unvaccinated, 14.3% were sick, 1.6% of those vaccinated with one dose, and 2% of those vaccinated with two doses.
The authors conclude that to prevent outbreaks, a higher coverage of vaccination with two doses is required.

points.title: Measles, mumps, rubella, and varicella combination vaccine: safety and immunogenicity alone and in combination with other vaccines given to children. Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Varicella Vaccine Study Group.
points.digest: After MMRV, much less chickenpox antibodies are formed than after a single vaccine, but more measles antibodies than MMR. More: [[1]==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9239770].

points.title: Exposure to varicella boosts immunity to herpes-zoster: implications for mass vaccination against chickenpox.
points.digest:
After infection, the chickenpox virus remains inactive in the neurons of the spinal ganglia, and after several decades, due to the weakening of cellular immunity, can again activate and cause shingles. The first who suggested that contact with sick chickenpox reduces the risk of herpes zoster, was Hope-Simpson in 1965. This phenomenon is called exogenous boosting, which, by the way, is the same Hope-Simpson, who first suggested that the flu epidemiology depends not so much on the virus as on the sun. One of the dangers of vaccines which is usually neglected, is that if contact with chickenpox really reduces the risk of re-reactivation of the virus, then massive vaccination will lead to an increase in the incidence of shingles.
In a study conducted in England in 1991, it was found that adults who live with children, are infected with shingles 25% less. It is estimated that contact with sick chickenpox provides protection from herpes zoster for an average of 20 years. Based on these data, the authors constructed a mathematical model and concluded that mass vaccination would lead to epidemic of herpes zoster that will last 30-50 years . 50% of people between the ages of 10 and 44 are ill with shingles, and only 46 years later the incidence will drop to the level of the pre-vaccination era.

points.title: Varicella-zoster virus vaccination under the exogenous boosting hypothesis: two ethical perspectives.
points.digest:
Due to the effect of exogenous boosting, a reduction in the incidence of chickenpox leads to an increase in the incidence of herpes zoster, mass vaccination raises an ethical issue. The health prospects of one group of people are increasing due to the health damage of another group. Despite the fact that the program of mass vaccination from chickenpox was started in several countries, while other countries are waiting for the final results of studies of the effect of exogenous boosting, an attempt at an ethical analysis of vaccination before The question of vaccination can not be resolved through simple ethical rules such as respecting autonomy (graft) or "do not harm others" (not being vaccinated). requires a balance between the competing interests of different groups and therefore requires a more complex ethical approach.
Authors view this ethical issue through two fundamental ethical approaches: classical utilitarianism and contractualism. The utilitarian approach is based on two prerequisites Kah: (1) the effect of selection on the well-being (happiness or health) is the only aspect really having a value, and (2) well-being of each equally important. That is, what is important in choosing alternatives is an increase in the average level of well-being.
In the case of chickenpox, thus, the question is whether vaccination will reduce the overall incidence. Despite the fact that empirical evidence from the US indicates a drop in hospitalization due to chickenpox by 88%, and a 74% reduction in mortality, these data do not take into account the influence on the elderly. If we take it into account, then vaccination becomes already unattractive, since it is estimated that an increase in the incidence of shingles will exceed the decrease in the incidence of chickenpox.
Therefore, according to classical utilitarianism, mass vaccination is undesirable.

From the point of view of contractualism, an ethical decision is determined not consequences, but an excuse in terms of the principles and rules arising from the hypothetical "social contract". This agreement is concluded between all people and it determines which fundamental rules should govern the society. That is, unlike the utilitarian approach, what is important is not the quantitative benefit of vaccination, but whether its introduction can be justified from the point of view of generally accepted principles. Principles that should also be acceptable to those who lose from it - adults and elderly. The following considerations are considered: 1) Freedom protection of one's health (through vaccination).
2) Responsibility . Elderly can be cured from the herpes zoster. Vaccination from it is considered safe.
3) Unacceptable sacrifices . Some elderly people will not be able to protect themselves from shingles (because the vaccine is not effective or contraindicated). These people will be sacrificed for the benefit of a large group of children. However, since the shingles are rarely flying, this sacrifice is perfectly acceptable.
4) Uncertainty. Although exogenous booster exists, its effect on the incidence of shingles is less established than the effect of vaccination on the incidence of chickenpox. Therefore, it may be necessary to attach greater importance to something already established than something not yet fully established.
Therefore, from the point of view of contractualism, mass vaccination is justified, since it is unclear why children should protect the elderly. Contractualism emphasizes impartial a priori rules, and not a posteriori consequences and, therefore, is less dependent on quantitative estimates of these consequences. The authors conclude that the decision to introduce vaccination should be based not only on quantitative data and research, but also on ethical prerequisites.

points.title: Vaccination to prevent varicella.
points.digest:
- Since in the overwhelming majority of cases, chickenpox in childhood is a very mild disease, vaccinated against it [started==https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25721380] to reduce the insignificant lethality or the number of hospitalizations, but more so that parents do not miss work on those days when the child does not attend school or kindergarten because of illness.
The economic viability of the vaccination was based on the following assumptions:
1) The price of the vaccine is $ 35, and it costs another $35.
However, after licensing, the price of the vaccine has doubled.
2) One dose of the vaccine gives immunity for life.
Subsequently it turned out that this is not the case, and another dose was administered.
3) The effectiveness of the vaccine is 85-95%, and the side effects are insignificant.
When high vaccine effectiveness was provided by exogenous boosting (ie contact with patients) When, thanks to vaccination, contact with patients became rare, the effectiveness of the vaccine decreased to 80% and lower.
4) Universal vaccination does not affect the incidence of shingles.
It turned out that the incidence of opaia yvayuschim deprive grown.
5) The annual cost of the vaccination program was estimated at $ 162 million, while the savings in health care costs due to chickenpox was $ 80 million. That is, the cost of the vaccination program was two times higher than the estimated savings. But taking into account the fact that parents should miss working days (which cost $ 392 million a year), vaccination with a single dose was economically justified.

- In clinical trials, the effectiveness of the vaccine is overestimated because the diseased children whose PCR analysis does not confirm the presence of the virus , or the sample for analysis does not meet the requirements, are excluded from the study.
- The UK Ministry of Health concluded that a two-dose vaccination will probably be economically justified, but only 80-100 + years after the start of vaccination.

Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae) lives in the nasopharynx of 5%-90% of healthy people. Among schoolchildren, bacteria occur in 20% -60%, among soldiers - 50% -60%, among childless adults - 5%-10%.
The connection between colonization of pneumococcus and natural immunity is poorly understood. Pneumococcus can lead to pneumonia, bacteremia and meningitis.Exact statistics on pneumococcus are not available, but it is estimated that every year in the USA, 400,000 people suffer from pneumococcal pneumonia (lethality 5% -7%), 12,000 - bacteremia (mortality rate 20%, and among the elderly 60%), and 3000-6000 - meningitis (summer The risk factors for invasive pneumococcal infection include smoking, leukemia, HIV and other immunodeficient conditions, the absence of the spleen, the presence of cochlear implants, kidney failure, liver disease and other chronic diseases. The risk of invasive infection is also increased among Alaska Natives, Negroes and some Indian tribes.
With a decrease in the incidence of Hib, pneumococcus has become the leading cause of bacterial meningitis among children under 5 in the US. comfort 92 serotypes of pneumococcus. The 10 most common serotypes are responsible for 62% of invasive diseases.
The first conjugate pneumococcal vaccine was licensed in 2000, and included 7 serotypes (PCV7). In 2010, a vaccine was licensed from 13 serotypes (PCV13). There is also a polysaccharide 23-valent vaccine against pneumococcus (licensed in 1983), which is used today for the elderly. By 2020, the goal is to achieve 90% coverage of vaccination among the elderly. Older people also recommend a dose of PCV13, but this recommendation will be reconsidered in 2018.
The immunity of pneumococcus to penicillin and other antibiotics was very common, but after the vaccination of PCV7 it began to decrease and then increased again, then in 2008, the determination of immunity to penicillin has been changed, and today it is believed that most of the strains are susceptible to penicillin. It turned out that clinical immunity to penicillin differs from susceptibility in vitro.
Vaccine [contains==https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/appendices/B/excipient-table-2.pdf] aluminum and polysorbate 80. The vaccine is usually done at 2, 4, 6 and 12 months.
